document.docAuthor: Ravichandran, S., Vigneshwaran, P. & Rameshkumar, G.
document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic review of the fish parasitic isopod family Cymothoidae Leach, 1818 (Crustacea: Isopoda: Cymothooidea) of India

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A taxonomic review of the fish parasitic isopod family Cymothoidae Leach, 1818 (Crustacea: Isopoda: Cymothooidea) of India

subSubSection.paragraph: ( Fig. 3 j–l)

Livoneca Renardi Bleeker, 1857: 28–29
, pl. 1 (fig. 8).

Irona Renardi .
— Schiöedte & Meinert, 1884: 383–386 , pl. XIV (Cym. XXXIV), figs 10–15.

Livoneca Renardi .
—Gerstaecker, 1882: 261.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Irona melanosticta
.— Barnard, 1914: 373–374 ; 1955: 6.—
Kensley, 1978: 80
, fig. 33a (non
I. melanosticta Schiöedte & Meinert, 1884
).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Irona renardi .
— Nierstrasz, 1915: 104 ; 1931: 145 .— Hale, 1926: 218–220 , fig. 12; 1929: 258, fig. 255.— Holthuis, 1959: 97 , pl. 11 (figs 4–9).— Monod, 1971: 173–174 ; 1976: 863 , figs 30, 32.— Trilles, 1976: 785–786 , pl. 11 (fig. 10); 1979: 266.— Beumer, Ashburner, Burbury, Jette & Latham, 1982: 32.

Mothocya renardi
.—
Bruce, 1986: 1169–1177
, figs 49–52, 55.—Williams & Williams, 1986: 215. Kazmi, Schotte & Yousuf, 2002: 102 , fig. 84.— Yu & Li, 2003: 230–232 , fig. 6.— Jones, Miller, Grutter & Cribb, 2008: 477–491 .—Aneesh, Sudha, Helna, Arshad, Anilkumar & Trilles, 2013: 1–9 .— Trilles, Ravichandran & Rameshkumar, 2011: 451 .— Rameshkumar, Ravichandran & Allayie, 2013b: 127–132 .— Hadfield, Bruce & Smit, 2015: 150–155 , fig. 3, 4, 9 (b).—Aneesh, Helna & Sudha, 2016: 1270–1277 , fig. 2j–m.—
Ravichandran, Sivasubramanian, Rameshkumar & Veerappan 2016b: 1386–1391
, fig. 2.—Aneesh, Sudha, Helna, & Anilkumar, 2016: 583–599, figs 1–6.

Lironeca puhi
.—Ravichandran, 2007: 87–93, figs 2, 3.

Not
Lironeca renardi
.— Miers, 1880: 465–466 .

Not
Irona renardii
.—Lanzing & O’Connor, 1975: 355–361, fig. 1c, d
[
Mothocya halei
]
.

Type and type locality .
Syntype , held at Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historie , Leiden , The Netherlands ( RMNH No. 78)
.
Bleeker (1857) gives ‘...la mer de Batavia. ’ as the locality. The data on the oldest of the three labels with specimens 4611 gives ‘ Baai van Batavia , Java’. However, there is no label in Bleeker’s own hand writing. The type locality is here taken to be Jakarta Bay, Java , Indonesia
.

Material examined. 5 ovig. females, ( 25–34 mm ), Pazhaiyar, 22 September 2016 ( CAS / MBRM C- 186– C- 190), 3 non ovig. females (25–35), Pazhaiyar, 22 September 2016 , from
Strongylura leiura
, coll. D. Karthick Rajan ( CAS / MBRM C- 191– C- 192). 1 ovig. female ( 30 mm ), Parangipettai, 17 July 2017 , from
Strongylura leiura ,
coll. S. Ravichandran ( ZSI / MBRC D1-540) all localities from the southeast coast of India .

Remark. Previously briefly described by Bleeker (1857) ,
Mothocya renardi
was most recently carefully treated and redescribed by Bruce, (1986) and
Hadfield et al. (2015)
. The Indian material
Mothocya renardi
was most recently redescribed and updated the lifecycle by Aneesh et al. (2006).
Mothocya renardi
can be distinguished by the large size ( 25–34 mm in length), narrow pleon and long narrow uropods, which extend well past the posterior margin of the pleotelson.

Variation is seen among
M. renardi
specimens from different regions (as is known for other cymothoid species; see Aneesh et al. 2006). Those specimens from the southwestern host of India average 30 mm , those from the Indo–Malaysian and northern Pacific regions average 27 mm (
Hadfield et al. 2014c
, 2015 ), and those from Australia average 29 mm in total length ( Bruce 1986 ). Specimens also differ in body shape, widest pereonite, shape of pleotelson and pereopod 7 propodus.

The other southern Indian
Mothocya
species,
M. karobran
,
M. melanosticta
and
M. plagulophora
, are easily distinguished from
M. renardi
.
Mothocya renardi
has longerr uropods, a wider pleon, shorter coxae, and longer pleopods than
M. melanosticta
. It also has larger coxae, a much narrower pleon and pleotelson, longer uropods, and larger peduncle and posteromedial lobes on the pleopods than
M. karobran
.

When compared with the description of the syntypes given by Bruce (1986) , specimens from India are broader with a moderately twisted pleon in relation to the plane of the pereon. Furthermore, the maxilla lateral lobe has two rather than three recurved robust setae, the propodal palm on pereopod 7 does not form a shallow lobe, and the exopod is 1.4 rather than 1.6 times longer than endopod.

Ravichandran’s (2007) figure of
Ichthyoxenos puhi (Bowman, 1962)
(as
Lironeca puhi Bowman, 1962
) from the host
Strongylura leiura (Bleeker, 1850)
is a misidentification and refers to
M. renardi
based on the morphology. The large size ( 24–36 mm in length), narrow pleon and long narrow uropods, which extend well past the posterior margin of the pleotelson are important characteristics that define the species ( Bruce 1986 ;
Hadfield et al. 2015
). Similarly, Lanzing & O’Connor’s (1975) figure of
Irona renardii
from the host
Girella tricuspidata (Quoy & Gaimard, 1824)
from estuaries and coastal waters of eastern Australia is also a misidentification and refers to
Mothocya halei Bruce, 1986
.
Colour. In alcohol, colour varied from pale tan to dark red; chromatophores scattered over dorsum and present on most appendages ( Bruce 1986 ).
Size. Ovig. females 24–36 mm ; non ovig. females 26–35; males 15–23 mm ( Bruce 1986 ).

Hosts. The most frequently recorded host is
Strongylura leiura (Bleeker, 1850)
(sometimes cited as
Tylosurus leiurus
or
Belone ciconia
). Hale (1926) recorded it from
Strongylura leiura
(cited as
Tylosurus ferox
, presumably
Belone ferox
, which is a junior synonym of
S. leiura
) and
Tylosurus gavialoides (Castelnau, 1873)
(cited as
Tylosurus macleayana
, presumably
Belone macleayana
, which is a junior synonym for
T. gavialoides
). Other host species are
Strongylura anastomella (Valenciennes, 1846)
,
S. incise (Valenciennes, 1846)
,
S. strongylura (van Hasselt, 1823)
and
Tylosurus crocodilus (Péron & Lesueur, 1821) ( Bruce 1986 )
. Bruce (1986) reported
M. renardi
from ‘
Strongylura crocodilis
(recorded as
S. choram
)’ ( Bruce 1986: 1174 ) as the host from the Zambezi River estuary (SAM A2675); however, the original label records the host as
Tylosurus choram (Rüppell, 1837)
, adding another host record for this species.
